title: C√≥digo de conducta
text:
La comunidad de Estaci√≥n R, incluyendo sus representantes, deben conocer y seguir este C√≥digo de Conducta (basado en el C√≥digo de Conducta de R Community) que es establecido con la finalidad de alentar al crecimiento de esta comunidad, participando en un ambiente amigable y partiendo de la base del respeto mutuo.
Este c√≥digo de conducta aplica en todos los espacios de participaci√≥n de Estaci√≥n R, incluyendo reuniones, Twitter, Slack, listas de correo, tanto online como offline. Tambi√©n es aplicable fuera de los espacios del grupo a quienes act√∫en en representaci√≥n del mismo, ya sea online u offline.
En cualquier tipo de evento ya sea conferencia, charla, taller, fiesta, reuni√≥n, redes sociales y otros medios en l√≠nea:

Aborde los esfuerzos ajenos con consideraci√≥n;
Cuando no est√© de acuerdo con algo, sea amable al plantear sus problemas;
Ejercite la consideraci√≥n y el respeto en su discurso y en sus acciones;
Intente colaborar para evitar conflictos;
Sea consciente de su entorno y del resto de las personas;
Alerte a quien considere oportuno si nota alguna situaci√≥n peligrosa, alguien sufriendo una situaci√≥n comprometedora o violaciones de este C√≥digo de Conducta, incluso aunque parezcan poco importantes. Responderemos tan pronto como podamos.

Esperamos que Estaci√≥n R sea un grupo libre de acoso.
Acoso incluye, entre otros: insultos, tanto directos como indirectos; da√±o o perjurio verbal o escrito relacionado con g√©nero, orientaci√≥n sexual, raza, religi√≥n, incapacidad; uso inapropiado de im√°genes de desnudez (incluyendo presentaciones digitales); intimidaci√≥n deliberada, acecho o persecuci√≥n; fotograf√≠as o grabaciones abusivas; interrupci√≥n sostenida de presentaciones u de otros eventos; contacto f√≠sico inapropiado y atenci√≥n sexual no deseada.
Quienes violen estas reglas podr√≠an recibir una sanci√≥n o explusi√≥n del grupo. Si se te pide que detengas cualquier comportamiento que se considere como acoso, esperamos que lo detengas de inmediato.
Somos receptivos a los comentarios constructivos y las cr√≠ticas, ya que las experiencias y conjuntos de habilidades de otras personas contribuyen a todos nuestros esfuerzos. Aceptamos a cualquiera que desee participar en nuestras actividades. Fomentanmos un entorno en el que quien lo desee pueda aportar y marcar la diferencia.

Veedores del C√≥digo de Conducta
Este c√≥digo de conducta ser√° aplicado por integrantes de Estaci√≥n R. En caso de disputas que involucren a alguien que es parte del grupo designado, √©sta persona se har√° a un lado en la toma de decisiones.

title: Blending R and Python in Quarto documents
text: Data science teams are increasingly ‚Äúmultilingual‚Äù, using more than one statistical computing tool for analyses and models. While many typesetting and notebook approaches support more than one language, Quarto is specifically designed for this flexibility. In particular, Quarto offers the ability to combine source code in both R and python into one single, reproducible document. These new capabilities have made it easier than ever to incorporate both languages simultaneously into statistics and data science courses. In this talk, I will give an overview of the advantages and drawbacks of using Quarto for ‚Äúbilingual‚Äù materials in the data science classroom. I‚Äôll also offer some tips and tricks - as well as some helper scripts - for managing these blended documents.

Speaker





Kelly Bodwin is an Associate Professor of Statistics and Data Science at Cal Poly, in San Luis Obispo, CA. Her research includes R package development, studies of statistical education, and applications in a variety of fields such as history, biology, and viticulture. While R will always be her first love, she is slowly learning to accept python into her life.

Ejercicio 1: Instalar los paquetes tidyverse, rio y eph (si a√∫n no los tienen instalados) y luego cargarlos en el entorno de R (library()). Comprobar que al cargarlos no surja ning√∫n error.

Ejercicio 1: Abrir el proyecto creado en clase, que contiene la base de nombres de personas. En su defecto, crear un proyecto nuevo, con una carpeta en su interior llamada datos y ubicar en esa carpeta la base de nombre de personas para el a√±o 2015, vista en clase.
Ejercicio 2: Una vez en el proyecto, crear un script nuevo y en √©l escribir la sentencia necesaria para importar la base de nombres de personas - 2015 a nuestro Ambiente (Environment) de Rstudio. Recordar guardar en un objeto esa base.
Ejercicio 3: Ejecutar las siguientes funciones sobre el data frame base_personas y describir con un comentario (#) en el script lo que realiza cada una de ellas.

title: Introducci√≥n a R base

Data Frames

Un Data Frame (o tabla) es la combinaci√≥n de vectores (variables), que termina conformando una relaci√≥n entre filas y columnas.
Cada vector es una columna de un dataframe, y cada uno de sus valores, en el orden en que se encuentran, conforman las filas.

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Data Frames

Para crear un Data Frame puedo utilizar la funci√≥n data.frame(), cuyos inputs son los vectores:

                            vector_nombre)

‚ÄúLa visualizaci√≥n es el proceso de hacer visibles los contrastes, ritmos y eventos que los datos expresan, que no podemos percibir cuando vienen en forma de √°ridas listas de n√∫meros y categor√≠as.‚Äù 1

title: Visualizaci√≥n de datos con {ggplot2}
text:
¬øQu√© es {ggplot2}?


Una implementaci√≥n del sistema Grammar of graphics (Wilkinson, 2005).



Un esquema pensado en capas (datos ‚Äì> plano (ejes x e y) ‚Äì> geometr√≠as)



Un paquete de funciones de aplicaci√≥n intuitiva.

title: Visualizaci√≥n de datos con {ggplot2}
text:
¬øPor qu√© {ggplot2}?


Tiene un marco de referencia (El grammar of graphics)
Flexible, con especificaciones a nivel de capas.
Sistema de themes, que permiten pulir la apariencia del gr√°fico
Decenas de extensiones para ampliar la potencia del paquete
Comunidad activa y con mucha predisposici√≥n a ayudar.

title: Quarto and automation in teaching statistical computing
text: In this talk we will discuss the use of GitHub actions and Quarto to provide automated feedback to students in a variety of statistical computing courses. These courses span the undergraduate and graduate curriculum and make use of both R and Python. The flexibility and power of the Quarto framework provide for the development of common tooling and workflows that can be adapted the specific needs of each course. We will provide concrete examples of how these tools are currently being used in these courses as well as discussing how they can be extended and adopted for new courses.

Pasos a seguir

3. Solo Windows: Instalar Rtools

4. Ejecutar script de puesta a punto
Descarg√° y ejecut√° el siguiente script en RStudio:

# ============================================
# SCRIPT DE PUESTA A PUNTO
# Curso: Intro al Procesamiento de Datos con R
# ============================================

# 1. Instalar pacman (gestor de paquetes)
if (!require("pacman")) {
  install.packages("pacman")
}
library(pacman)

# 2. Instalar y cargar paquetes del curso
p_load(
  "tidyverse",   # Manipulaci√≥n y visualizaci√≥n de datos
  "haven",       # Leer archivos SPSS, Stata, SAS
  "readxl",      # Leer archivos Excel
  "janitor",     # Limpieza de datos
  "eph",         # Datos de la EPH Argentina
  "gt",          # Tablas elegantes
  "scales"       # Formateo de escalas
)

# 3. Verificar instalaci√≥n
cat("\n‚úì ¬°Paquetes instalados correctamente!\n")
cat("Versi√≥n de R:", R.version.string, "\n")
cat("Versi√≥n de tidyverse:", as.character(packageVersion("tidyverse")), "\n")

# 4. Prueba r√°pida
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +
  geom_point(color = "#2E86AB", size = 3) +
  labs(
    title = "¬°Todo funciona!",
    subtitle = "Est√°s listo/a para el curso"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

Tambi√©n pod√©s descargar el script directamente: 00-puesta_a_punto.R

title: Teaching Quarto in Introduction to Data Science Courses
text: Quarto, the next-generation version of R Markdown, is a powerful tool that helps students be more of an active participant in class while simultaneously highlighting the importance of reproducibility in science. In this talk, we discuss how to facilitate the use of Quarto into classroom pedagogy for students who are learning the programming language R and Quarto at the same time. In combination with R, this tool can help instructions create interactive live-coding experiences for students. Features of Quarto provide multiple ways for students to write code and type written answers to questions on their own, in groups, or along with the instructor during lecture. Students can also learn to create their own project reports, and turn their projects into hosted websites. In this session, we share how Quarto is used in an Introductory Data Science course for students with little to no coding experience at Duke University. Further, we go into benefits and challenges of teaching with Quarto from both the instructor and student perspective.

title: Teaching Quarto in Introduction to Data Science Courses
text: Quarto, the next-generation version of R Markdown, is a powerful tool that helps students be more of an active participant in class while simultaneously highlighting the importance of reproducibility in science. In this talk, we discuss how to facilitate the use of Quarto into classroom pedagogy for students who are learning the programming language R and Quarto at the same time. In combination with R, this tool can help instructions create interactive live-coding experiences for students. Features of Quarto provide multiple ways for students to write code and type written answers to questions on their own, in groups, or along with the instructor during lecture. Students can also learn to create their own project reports, and turn their projects into hosted websites. In this session, we share how Quarto is used in an Introductory Data Science course for students with little to no coding experience at Duke University. Further, we go into benefits and challenges of teaching with Quarto from both the instructor and student perspective.

Elijah Meyer (elijah.meyer@duke.edu) is currently a teaching postdoctoral associate at Duke University. Taught Quarto in introductory data science at Duke the last fall, spring, and summer sessions. His work focuses on curricula and course creation, as well as studying how to best support newer instructor‚Äôs use of active learning.

Desde elegir con qu√© columnas (variables) vamos a trabajar; definir cu√°l es nuestra poblaci√≥n de estudio (filas); crear variables nuevas (indicadores) o editar existentes (recodificar); ordenar la base en funci√≥n de variables espec√≠ficas y crear c√°lculos que permitan extraer algunas conclusiones (o m√°s preguntas) en base a la informaci√≥n con la que contamos.

title: Analisis PUNA
text:
library(tidyverse)

‚îÄ‚îÄ Attaching core tidyverse packages ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse 2.0.0 ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úî dplyr     1.1.4     ‚úî readr     2.1.6
‚úî forcats   1.0.1     ‚úî stringr   1.6.0
‚úî ggplot2   4.0.1     ‚úî tibble    3.3.1
‚úî lubridate 1.9.4     ‚úî tidyr     1.3.2
‚úî purrr     1.2.1     
‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úñ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
‚úñ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
‚Ñπ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors






df_puna <- read.csv("../../data/puna_base_agregada.csv", encoding = "latin1")





tabla <- df_puna %>%
  filter(indice_tiempo == 2022) %>%
  group_by(tipo) %>%
  summarise(cant_habitantes = sum(habitaciones, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  mutate(porc_habitantes = round(cant_habitantes / sum(cant_habitantes) * 100, 1))

tabla

# A tibble: 3 √ó 3
  tipo             cant_habitantes porc_habitantes
  <chr>                      <int>           <dbl>
1 Hoteleros                 185351            75.1
2 Otros colectivos            2810             1.1
3 Parahoteleros              58490            23.7






ggplot(data = tabla, 
       aes(y = cant_habitantes, x = fct_reorder(tipo, -cant_habitantes))) +
  geom_col(aes(fill = tipo)) +
  # geom_text(aes(label = format(cant_habitantes, big.mark = ".")),
  #           vjust = "inward") +
  geom_text(aes(label = paste0(format(cant_habitantes,
                                      big.mark = "."), "(",porc_habitantes, "%)")),
            vjust = "inward") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0, color = "grey") + 
  scale_fill_brewer(type = "qual", 
                    palette = 3) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

title: Using Quarto for Making and Organizing Teaching Materials
text: In addition to creating reproducible documents, Quarto offers a rich suite of options for creation slide decks, books, and websites, allowing instructors to create all of their teaching materials reproducibly. In this talk we will demo how we‚Äôve been using Quarto to create and organize teaching materials, introduce resources and templates for getting started with Quarto for organizing your own teaching materials, and share best practices.

Speaker





Maria Tackett is an Assistant Professor of the Practice in the Department of Statistical Science at Duke University. Her research focuses on understanding factors that impact students‚Äô sense of belonging in introductory math and statistics courses with the aim to identify pedagogies that foster community and a supportive learning environment. She‚Äôs an active member of the statistics education community and its effort to make statistics more engaging and accessible for all students.
